seven dinner meetings involving
7,500 Baltimore area alumni of
the Homewood Schools, according to an announcement by Dr.
J. H. Fitzgerald Dunning, Chairman of Maryland Homewood
Committee.
Invitations have been sent to
all Homewood graduates of The
Johns Hopkins University living
in Baltimore according to the
year of their graduation. Those
attending the dinner meetings
will form the nucleus of the
group which will contact all
other Homewood alumni in Baltimore.
This special appeal to Johns
Hopkins alumni is being conducted simultaneously but in addition to the annual Alumni Roll
Call. The occasion for the special effort is the University's
need to provide matching funds
in the amount of $12,000,000 to
qualify for a Ford Foundation
grant of $6,000,000 announced
last spring.
The dinner meetings will feature appearances by University
trustees and administrative officials, who will explain to the
alumni groups the University's
m syfor raising the necessary
plans

The complete schedule of the
meetings, including dates, and
participating groups, is as follows:
Oct. 2—Classes of the 1920's.
Oct. 4—Classes of the 1930's.
Oct. 9—Classes of the 1940's.
Oct. 10—Classes of 1919 and
earlier.
• Oct. 11—Classes of 1950 through
'54.
Oct. 16-- Clas.ses of 1955 through
'59.
Oct. 18--Graduate Classes.
All meetings will be held in
the Clipper Room of Shriver
Hall beginning with a reception
at 5:30 p.m. and dinner 4t 6:15
p.m. except for the meeting of
October 10, which will be held
in the Tap Room of the Johns
Hopkins Club.
In making the announcement
of the extensive series of meetings, Dr. Dunning explained that
the University in 1960 received a
conditional
Ford
Foundation
grant of $6,000,000 which required the raising of $12,000,000
in matching funds.
This challenge was met in half
the time allotted and last spring
the Ford Foundation significantly saw fit to award Johns Hopkins an unprecedented second
conditional grant of $6,000,000
which requires the raising of an
additional $12,000,000 of matching funds.
"The $12,000,00 to match the
first grant was raised largely
from foundations, corporations,
some alumni, and other nonalumni sources." Dr. Dunning
explained. "Toward the second
grant the University must look
to the balance of the alumni of
Johns Hopkins for a greater
share. We must secure the interest and support of the alumni in
a most convincing manner before
we can again approach nonalumni sources who have given
so generously already."

Barnstormers, Playshop Hassle
Over Barn Use For Rehearsals
A conflict over the use of the
barn for dramatic rehearsals has
arisen between the "Barnstormers", campus thespian organization, and the "Playshop", a community theatre group.
The "Playshop" has had full
use of the Barn facilities while
rehearsing for "The Beaver
Coat", scheduled for production
in November. At the same time,
these facilities were needed by
the "Barnstormers" in preparation for this year's Freshman
play, "Visit to a Small Planet".
Both groups maintained that
they had equal right to use the
building for their respective rehearsals.
Immediate reaction came from
president Peter
Barnstormer
Grossman who said: "The batn
is a building for undergraduate
affairs and it was my understanding that the undergraduates could have use of the building fifty percent of the time.
I feel that this agreement is not
being fulfilled."
Grossman made an appeal to
the Student Activities Commission which oversees campus activities. In a unanimous vote.

the Commission recommended to
Dr. Morrill that undergraduate
rehearsals should take precedence over those of the "Playshop".
A temporary agreement between the theatre groups was
established whereby the "Playshop" would rehearse on Monday's, Wednesday's, and Friday's.
and the "Barnstormers' on Tuesday's and Thursday's. However,

television screen on a hot night last July. Perhaps
you remember that it originated from France. And
that it reached the U. S. via Telstar, the world's first
private enterprise communications satellite.

success that glowed brightly on the faces of all who
shared in the project.

Since that summer night, the Bell System's Telstar
has relayed electronic signals of many types — television broadcasts, telephone calls, news photographs,
and others.

These Bell System people, through their talented,
dedicated efforts, make your phone service still better,

Undergrads'
Class Abroad
Opens Feb.2
The application period for
spring semester study programs
conducted at the Universities of
Vienna and Freiburg by the Institute of European Studies will
open officially on Monday, October 8.
Each program includes formal
classes, lectures, seminars and
field-study in Europe, and is
designed to fulfill usual course
requirements at its academic
level.
The program at the University
of Vienna will admit those with
sophomore or junior standing as
of Feb. 2, 1963. It will combine
English-taught liberal arts and
general studies courses, intensive
German language instruction,
regular university courses taught
in German for those competent
in that language, and supplementary lectures and seminars.
Previous knowledge of German is
not required.
The "Das Deutsche Semester"
program at the University of
Freiburg is intended only for
juniors. It will stress political
science, German language study,
German philosophy and literature, and European history. All
classes will be taught in German.
Each program requires a Cplus college average. The Institute said admission will depend on the student's academic
achievement and the recommendations of his dean and department chairman and of a
professor familiar with his recent college work.
The application period will
close next December 10. Students
will sail for Europe from New
York February 2.
A descriptive brochure on the
two programs is available from
the Institute of European Studies, 35 E. Wacker Drive, Chicago. The Institute, a nonprofit
educational institution, conducts
full-year programs in Vienna,
Freiburg, and Paris. There is no
spring program in Paris.
Officials said students will be
led by academic guides on fieldstudy trips in western Europe.
The Institute said that more
than 200 U.S. colleges and universities have accepted credits
earned by their students on Institute programs.

A Shot In The Dark
It is shocking to view the mass irresponsibility of
the students enrolled at the University of Mississippi,
for it is on their hands rather than on the hands of
their elders that the bloodstains of immaturity and wishful thinking will remain.
With conservative restraint on our part, the governor and people of the oligarchy of "Ole Miss" can be
granted ignorance, prejudice and an outdated position
on states rights. However, more restraint is needed in
evaluating the effect of outright affirmations of white
supremacy on the student hotly of the University of
Mississippi.
Riots on the part of university students start in
our opinion, because of their intrinsic excitement, not
for purposes of forwarding causes. As University students ourselves we can sympathize with the efforts of
maturing adolescents who, in their maturing, endeavor
to create jovial collegiate atmospheres, and who often
indulge in wanton frivolity as they face the burdens of
adult life.
However, we can but marvel and be frightened at
the gross inability of Mississippi students to take a
positive position on the singular issue of international
significance which occurred not only on ground upon
which they tread, but on ground which we presume
they love.
Missing from our headlines and the news stories of
our press are orderly and thoughtful protests on the
part of Mississippi students on any position whatsoever.
We do not doubt that they did vocalize, but are shocked
at their lack of ingenuity in provoking at least some
form of passive protest to the events ensuent in Oxford.
We read only of the yielding to professional agitators by the percentage-wise few university students remaining in Oxford. Or, we read of their mass exodus
homeward to enjoy a week of vacation while the world's
eyes are focused on historical events which they could
have changed.
We are frightened to speculate that this passivity
represents the general attitude among American undergraduates. If we view the situation in Mississippi as a
unique emergency giv ing two reactions, namely mass
hysteria or mass unconcern, we may be understating ihe
situation. Nevertheless, the question remains: Are the
reactions evoked in this extreme ease typical of those our
contemporaries would give in a more universal
emergency?

A Positive Contribution
This year's student leaders have brought an unprecedented degree of organization to Hopkins undergraduate affairs. As we were promised, there are more
committees, involving more participants in student government, than ever before.
We are pleasantly surprised to note that, in general,
the newly created Student Council committees will, besides inducing greater participation in student government, meet real needs. The committee to investigate work,
study and travel abroad can provide a centralized source
of information where one has long been sorely wanted.
Likewise. the "Committee to Re-evaluate Student Activities Funds" is in a position materially to improve a
marginal situation.
If, however, any real value is to come from this
great re-organization, it must avoid the pomposity which
has defeated similar efforts in the past. One has only
to recall last year's unfortunate incident of the Gentleman's Code Commission to see how self importance can
lead to organization for its own sake, an unrewarding
if not absolutely ridiculous spectacle.
If it avoids this tempting pitfall, and there is
every reason to hope that it will, the New Order may
make a significant positive contribution to the Homewood scene.

A Word From The Wise
We would like to issue a reminder that the NewsLetter will, as it has in the past, maintain the Veritas
Vos Liberabit column for any member of the Hopkins
community who wishes to disburden himself of well
phrased opinion and/or comment. While we welcome
contributions to this open column from students, faculty, administration and friends of the University, the
editors reserve the right of final decision on what will
appear in this space.

In the recent furor over the assassination of President McKinley,
it may have escaped your notice that a nationwide study of the
writing ability of American college students has just been
published.
The survey reveals an astonishing fact: that when students
have completed their freshman year and are no longer required
to take English, their writing skill progressively declines until
we come to the fantastic situation where graduating seniors
actually are poorer writers of English than incoming freshmen!

Many theories have been offered to account for this incredible
fact. Some say that seniors know less English than freshmen
because all seniors major in French. This is not true. No more
than 94 percent of seniors major in French. How about the
other six percent?
Well sir, of the other six percent, half—or three percent—
take physics, and it is not hard to understand how these poor
souls grow rusty in English when all they ever say is "E equals
MC squared."
Of the remaining three percent, two-thirds—or two percent—
major in whaling, and their English too grows feeble with
disuse. Whalers, as we all know, do not speak at all except to
shout, "Thar she blows!" maybe twice a year.
Of the one percent remaining, it cannot be fairly said that
they are poor writers. The fact is, we don't know what kind of
writers they are. Why not? Because they never write. And why
don't they ever write? Because this remaining one percent of
American college students are enrolled at the University of
Alaska, and never take their mittens off.
(Incidentally, I received quite a surprise upon first visiting
Alaska two years ago when I was invited to Juneau to crown
the Queen of the Annual Date Palm Festival. Frankly I cx-

pected to find a surly and morose populace. After all, going
through life with your mittens on all the time is hardly calculated to make you merry as a cricket. Not only can't you write,
but you miss out on all kinds of other fun things—like three
card monte, making shadow pictures on the wall, and lint picking. However, to my astonishment, I discovered Alaskans to
be a hale and gregarious group, mittens notwithstanding, and
I soon found out why: because mittens notwithstanding, they
could still smoke Marlboro Cigarettes, still enjoy that rich
mellow flavor, that fine, clean Selectrate filter, that truly soft
soft pack, that truly flip-top flip-top box—and that, friends,
will make anybody happy, mittens notwithstanding. In fact,
Alaskans are the happiest people I have ever met in the whole
United States—except, of course, for the Alaskan vendors of
Marlboro Cigarettes, who have not been paid in many years —
indeed, never—because how can anybody dig out coins to pay
for cigarettes when he is wearing mittens?)
But I digress. What are we going to do about this deplorable
condition where college students, having completed Freshman
English, become steadily less proficient in the use of the language? The answer is simple. We will make them take Freshman English all through college. In fact, we won't let them take
anything else! This solution, besides producing a nation of
graceful writers, will also solve another harrowing problem:
where to park on campus. If everybody takes nothing but
Freshman English, we can tear down all the schools of law,
medicine, engineering, and whaling, and turn them into parking
lots. Can't we?

is not the only great contribution Hopkins has to offer the
American intellectual community. This month The Johns
Hopkins Magazine features an
institution of our University
which has led American scholarship since its inception in 1927.
The History of Ideas, a philosophy which was originated by
Professor Arthur 0. Lovejoy of
Johns Hopkins, has been a controlling factor in the vein of
scholarly pursuits since the
1930's. The greatest proponent
of this method has long been
the History of Ideas Club which
still meets at Hopkins. The
Magazine has now attempted to
feature this venerable tradition
through the format of a slick
tabloid. Such an endeavor is
worthy of great praise, especially when the results are as favorable as those achieved.
An attempt to recreate the atmosphere of the Club is an almost impossible task. However,
in a difficult situation, creative
imagination achieved an excellent solution.

To The Editor:
The Class of 1966 is befuddled.
At the outset, the underlying
conceptions and main advantages of the second semester
rush schedule were explained.
The IFC and the administration
deemed them capable of enforcement, as distinguished from a
mere set of exhortations or injunctions which it is desirable to
observe but for the enforcement
of which there is no effective
machinery.
The Class of 1966 is surrounded by smiling faces, shining and
bejewelled fraternity pins, and
probably has shaken more warm
and limp hands in this past week
than any other class in the
history of this university.
The miscarriage of the program is not at all onesided. While
brothers mingle and distribute
that extra can of beer held so

closely to the heart (and frat
pin) to the delight of ogling
freshmen, the state of, or, rather
lack of, affairs in the freshman
dorms, have made the deprived
Class of 1966 all too curious
about the magic of fraternity
brotherhood.
The counterplay of the new
rules governing freshmen and
the new rules of rushing, which
are ideally to work hand in glove,
are pragmatically at odds. While
the former creates a vacuum,
the latter insures a spectacular
increase in fraternity membership. Logically, these could not

advanced study in the liberal
arts for the purpose of enabling
adults to acquire broader knowledge, deeper insight, and greater
understanding of man's cultural
heritage and the social, political
and scientific aspects of contemporary society."

grant of $47,600 to Johns Hopkins from the Carnegie Coi-poraton of New York.

The answer is:

It may seem illogical that the
Hopkins campus, one supposedly
composed of maturity-plus individuals, should feel the need
for a council of coordination,
especially since other colleges of
equal reputation have found a
student council unnecessary. The
very reverse, however, may be
true. Because of the maturity,
the individuality, and the desire
to project personal opinion, a
centralized channel for expression should be provided. This is
left to the discrimination of the
student.
It is hoped that its significance
and 'or contribution may be
clearly brought to the attention
of the freshmen whose still objective view of their university
has been exposed and possibly
influenced by a series of contradictions.
This year's president. Joe
Perotto, is determined to establish the council's position on
campus as more than a normal
activity. He wishes it to be recognized as a forum of this threefold community, to handle all of
the campus activities in agreement with the administration,
but with the desires of the students as a basis for action.
The Council meets Monday
night and encourages strongly
the attendance of students. Dennis Dundas and Pete Grossman
are temporary freshman representatives and wish to be available as a sounding board to the
Council body.

Health Service
To Administer
Polio Vaccine
The Student Health Service,
in an effort to help knock out
polio, will administer three fie
doses of oral vaccine. The first
dose will be given at the Health
Service (new dorms) on October
4-6; the second, November 15-17:
the third, January 10-12. The
vaccine is most effective when
all three doses are taken.
This free service is available
to students only. Members of
the
faculty
and
employees
should go to the Friends' Meeting House, located at 3107 North
Charles Street.

Undergrads'
Class Abroad
Opens Feb.2
The application period for
spring semester study programs
conducted at the Universities of
Vienna and Freiburg by the Institute of European Studies will
open officially on Monday, October 8.
Each program includes formal
classes, lectures, seminars and
field-study in Europe, and is
designed to fulfill usual course
requirements at its academic
level.
The program at the University
of Vienna will admit those with
sophomore or junior standing as
of Feb. 2, 1963. It will combine
English-taught liberal arts and
general studies courses, intensive
German language instruction,
regular university courses taught
in German for those competent
in that language, and supplementary lectures and seminars.
Previous knowledge of German is
not required.
The "Das Deutsche Semester"
program at the University of
Freiburg is intended only for
juniors. It will stress political
science, German language study,
German philosophy and literature, and European history. All
classes will be taught in German.
Each program requires a Cplus college average. The Institute said admission will depend on the student's academic
achievement and the recommendations of his dean and department chairman and of a
professor familiar with his recent college work.
The application period will
close next December 10. Students
will sail for Europe from New
York February 2.
A descriptive brochure on the
two programs is available from
the Institute of European Studies, 35 E. Wacker Drive, Chicago. The Institute, a nonprofit
educational institution, conducts
full-year programs in Vienna,
Freiburg, and Paris. There is no
spring program in Paris.
Officials said students will be
led by academic guides on fieldstudy trips in western Europe.
The Institute said that more
than 200 U.S. colleges and universities have accepted credits
earned by their students on Institute programs.

A Shot In The Dark
It is shocking to view the mass irresponsibility of
the students enrolled at the University of Mississippi,
for it is on their hands rather than on the hands of
their elders that the bloodstains of immaturity and wishful thinking will remain.
With conservative restraint on our part, the governor and people of the oligarchy of "Ole Miss" can be
granted ignorance, prejudice and an outdated position
on states rights. However, more restraint is needed in
evaluating the effect of outright affirmations of white
supremacy on the student hotly of the University of
Mississippi.
Riots on the part of university students start in
our opinion, because of their intrinsic excitement, not
for purposes of forwarding causes. As University students ourselves we can sympathize with the efforts of
maturing adolescents who, in their maturing, endeavor
to create jovial collegiate atmospheres, and who often
indulge in wanton frivolity as they face the burdens of
adult life.
However, we can but marvel and be frightened at
the gross inability of Mississippi students to take a
positive position on the singular issue of international
significance which occurred not only on ground upon
which they tread, but on ground which we presume
they love.
Missing from our headlines and the news stories of
our press are orderly and thoughtful protests on the
part of Mississippi students on any position whatsoever.
We do not doubt that they did vocalize, but are shocked
at their lack of ingenuity in provoking at least some
form of passive protest to the events ensuent in Oxford.
We read only of the yielding to professional agitators by the percentage-wise few university students remaining in Oxford. Or, we read of their mass exodus
homeward to enjoy a week of vacation while the world's
eyes are focused on historical events which they could
have changed.
We are frightened to speculate that this passivity
represents the general attitude among American undergraduates. If we view the situation in Mississippi as a
unique emergency giv ing two reactions, namely mass
hysteria or mass unconcern, we may be understating ihe
situation. Nevertheless, the question remains: Are the
reactions evoked in this extreme ease typical of those our
contemporaries would give in a more universal
emergency?

A Positive Contribution
This year's student leaders have brought an unprecedented degree of organization to Hopkins undergraduate affairs. As we were promised, there are more
committees, involving more participants in student government, than ever before.
We are pleasantly surprised to note that, in general,
the newly created Student Council committees will, besides inducing greater participation in student government, meet real needs. The committee to investigate work,
study and travel abroad can provide a centralized source
of information where one has long been sorely wanted.
Likewise. the "Committee to Re-evaluate Student Activities Funds" is in a position materially to improve a
marginal situation.
If, however, any real value is to come from this
great re-organization, it must avoid the pomposity which
has defeated similar efforts in the past. One has only
to recall last year's unfortunate incident of the Gentleman's Code Commission to see how self importance can
lead to organization for its own sake, an unrewarding
if not absolutely ridiculous spectacle.
If it avoids this tempting pitfall, and there is
every reason to hope that it will, the New Order may
make a significant positive contribution to the Homewood scene.

A Word From The Wise
We would like to issue a reminder that the NewsLetter will, as it has in the past, maintain the Veritas
Vos Liberabit column for any member of the Hopkins
community who wishes to disburden himself of well
phrased opinion and/or comment. While we welcome
contributions to this open column from students, faculty, administration and friends of the University, the
editors reserve the right of final decision on what will
appear in this space.

In the recent furor over the assassination of President McKinley,
it may have escaped your notice that a nationwide study of the
writing ability of American college students has just been
published.
The survey reveals an astonishing fact: that when students
have completed their freshman year and are no longer required
to take English, their writing skill progressively declines until
we come to the fantastic situation where graduating seniors
actually are poorer writers of English than incoming freshmen!

Many theories have been offered to account for this incredible
fact. Some say that seniors know less English than freshmen
because all seniors major in French. This is not true. No more
than 94 percent of seniors major in French. How about the
other six percent?
Well sir, of the other six percent, half—or three percent—
take physics, and it is not hard to understand how these poor
souls grow rusty in English when all they ever say is "E equals
MC squared."
Of the remaining three percent, two-thirds—or two percent—
major in whaling, and their English too grows feeble with
disuse. Whalers, as we all know, do not speak at all except to
shout, "Thar she blows!" maybe twice a year.
Of the one percent remaining, it cannot be fairly said that
they are poor writers. The fact is, we don't know what kind of
writers they are. Why not? Because they never write. And why
don't they ever write? Because this remaining one percent of
American college students are enrolled at the University of
Alaska, and never take their mittens off.
(Incidentally, I received quite a surprise upon first visiting
Alaska two years ago when I was invited to Juneau to crown
the Queen of the Annual Date Palm Festival. Frankly I cx-

pected to find a surly and morose populace. After all, going
through life with your mittens on all the time is hardly calculated to make you merry as a cricket. Not only can't you write,
but you miss out on all kinds of other fun things—like three
card monte, making shadow pictures on the wall, and lint picking. However, to my astonishment, I discovered Alaskans to
be a hale and gregarious group, mittens notwithstanding, and
I soon found out why: because mittens notwithstanding, they
could still smoke Marlboro Cigarettes, still enjoy that rich
mellow flavor, that fine, clean Selectrate filter, that truly soft
soft pack, that truly flip-top flip-top box—and that, friends,
will make anybody happy, mittens notwithstanding. In fact,
Alaskans are the happiest people I have ever met in the whole
United States—except, of course, for the Alaskan vendors of
Marlboro Cigarettes, who have not been paid in many years —
indeed, never—because how can anybody dig out coins to pay
for cigarettes when he is wearing mittens?)
But I digress. What are we going to do about this deplorable
condition where college students, having completed Freshman
English, become steadily less proficient in the use of the language? The answer is simple. We will make them take Freshman English all through college. In fact, we won't let them take
anything else! This solution, besides producing a nation of
graceful writers, will also solve another harrowing problem:
where to park on campus. If everybody takes nothing but
Freshman English, we can tear down all the schools of law,
medicine, engineering, and whaling, and turn them into parking
lots. Can't we?

is not the only great contribution Hopkins has to offer the
American intellectual community. This month The Johns
Hopkins Magazine features an
institution of our University
which has led American scholarship since its inception in 1927.
The History of Ideas, a philosophy which was originated by
Professor Arthur 0. Lovejoy of
Johns Hopkins, has been a controlling factor in the vein of
scholarly pursuits since the
1930's. The greatest proponent
of this method has long been
the History of Ideas Club which
still meets at Hopkins. The
Magazine has now attempted to
feature this venerable tradition
through the format of a slick
tabloid. Such an endeavor is
worthy of great praise, especially when the results are as favorable as those achieved.
An attempt to recreate the atmosphere of the Club is an almost impossible task. However,
in a difficult situation, creative
imagination achieved an excellent solution.
The Magazine article wittily
presents a paper discussing the
idea of progress as a value in
the scientific thought of our
age. This incisive account of the
attempt of science to remove
value judgments from its socalled "scientific method", clearly delineates the approach a

To The Editor:
The Class of 1966 is befuddled.
At the outset, the underlying
conceptions and main advantages of the second semester
rush schedule were explained.
The IFC and the administration
deemed them capable of enforcement, as distinguished from a
mere set of exhortations or injunctions which it is desirable to
observe but for the enforcement
of which there is no effective
machinery.
The Class of 1966 is surrounded by smiling faces, shining and
bejewelled fraternity pins, and
probably has shaken more warm
and limp hands in this past week
than any other class in the
history of this university.
The miscarriage of the program is not at all onesided. While
brothers mingle and distribute
that extra can of beer held so

closely to the heart (and frat
pin) to the delight of ogling
freshmen, the state of, or, rather
lack of, affairs in the freshman
dorms, have made the deprived
Class of 1966 all too curious
about the magic of fraternity
brotherhood.
The counterplay of the new
rules governing freshmen and
the new rules of rushing, which
are ideally to work hand in glove,
are pragmatically at odds. While
the former creates a vacuum,
the latter insures a spectacular
increase in fraternity membership. Logically, these could not
have been the envisioned conTw. roc+

The University is presently
conducting five "Seminars in
the History of Ideas" which have
been made available to parttime evening students in the
Program of higher education for
adults leading to the new degree,
Master of Liberal Arts.
The seminars, taught by four
of the University's outstanding
scholars, encompass the fields of
Political science, history, literature and biology.
"This program," Dr. Richard
A. Mumma, Dean of McCoy College, said. "is designed to provide the equivalent of a year of
advanced study in the liberal
arts for the purpose of enabling
adults to acquire broader knowledge, deeper insight, and greater
understanding of man's cultural
heritage and the social, political
and scientific aspects of contemporary society."
The experimental program is
being supported initially by a
grant of $47,600 to Johns Hopkins from the Carnegie Coi-poraton of New York.
Students studying for the degree will be required to complete
five full-year courses, at least
three of which must be History
of Ideas Seminar.
The first five Seminars being
Offered this year and the prolessors are:
"The Idea of Political Obligation", Dr. Thomas I. Cook.
Johns Hopkins professor of political science, both terms.
"Intellectual History of the
Middle Ages", Dr. John W. BaldWin, associate professor history,
both terms.
"Portraits of the Artist in
Modern European Literature",
be. Richard A. Macksey, assistant professor of writing, first
term.
"The Comic: In Theory and
Practice", Dr. Macksey, second
term.
"Organisms Through Time".
be. H. Bentley Glass, professor
Of biology, second term.
Applicants for admission to
the course, Dean Mumma exInained, must hold a bachelor's
degree from an approved college
or university with an average of
la or better in the latter half of
his undergraduate program, or
an advanced degree.

further information may be obtained from the Office of the
bean of McCoy College, Shrivel.

The answer is:

It may seem illogical that the
Hopkins campus, one supposedly
composed of maturity-plus individuals, should feel the need
for a council of coordination,
especially since other colleges of
equal reputation have found a
student council unnecessary. The
very reverse, however, may be
true. Because of the maturity,
the individuality, and the desire
to project personal opinion, a
centralized channel for expression should be provided. This is
left to the discrimination of the
student.
It is hoped that its significance
and 'or contribution may be
clearly brought to the attention
of the freshmen whose still objective view of their university
has been exposed and possibly
influenced by a series of contradictions.
This year's president. Joe
Perotto, is determined to establish the council's position on
campus as more than a normal
activity. He wishes it to be recognized as a forum of this threefold community, to handle all of
the campus activities in agreement with the administration,
but with the desires of the students as a basis for action.
The Council meets Monday
night and encourages strongly
the attendance of students. Dennis Dundas and Pete Grossman
are temporary freshman representatives and wish to be available as a sounding board to the
Council body.

Health Service
To Administer
Polio Vaccine
The Student Health Service,
in an effort to help knock out
polio, will administer three fie
doses of oral vaccine. The first
dose will be given at the Health
Service (new dorms) on October
4-6; the second, November 15-17:
the third, January 10-12. The
vaccine is most effective when
all three doses are taken.
This free service is available
to students only. Members of
the
faculty
and
employees
should go to the Friends' Meeting House, located at 3107 North
Charles Street.
